content.data: ToolUseBlock(id='call_2593f6a9dd4543f89afa4820', caller=None, input={'thought': 'NARRATIVE CONTEXT & STRUCTURE:\nThis is a "What If...? Dark" story — these one-shots explore darker, often tragic alternate timelines where familiar heroes make one fateful different choice, leading to catastrophic consequences. For Venom-Thing, the premise asks: What if the most physically powerful member of the Fantastic Four — the Ever-Lovin\' Blue-Eyed Thing — bonded with an alien symbiote that amplifies rage and aggression? The structure likely follows: (1) Post-Secret Wars, Ben returns from space emotionally raw and resentful over Reed\'s deception about curing his condition. (2) He discovers the "helpless" symbiote in Reed\'s lab. (3) The symbiote senses Ben\'s anger and vulnerability, whispering promises of power, acceptance, revenge. (4) Ben bonds. (5) Dark escalation — Venom-Thing likely loses control, possibly attacking his teammates. (6) Tragic climax where Ben\'s strength plus symbiote enhancement proves unstoppable. (7) Aftermath showing the cost of this choice. The "Dark" branding suggests this won\'t end well — Ben may become a villain or die tragically.', 'step_number': 1, 'total_steps': 4, 'branch': 'narrative context', 'is_final': False}, name='sequential_thinking', type='tool_use')

content.content: {"status": "thought_recorded", "step_recorded": 1, "steps_remaining": 3, "total_steps_so_far": 1, "suggested_next_aspect": "character motivations and relationships", "instruction": "Step 1 recorded. Continue to step 2 \u2014 suggested focus: 'character motivations and relationships'. 3 step(s) remaining before is_final=true."}

content.data: ToolUseBlock(id='call_32b00762d14947c58ddaad6f', caller=None, input={'thought': 'CHARACTER MOTIVATIONS & EMOTIONAL CORE:\nBen Grimm\'s tragedy is central here. Even without the symbiote, Ben carries tremendous burden — trapped in a monstrous rock-like form, created by his best friend Reed Richards. In mainstream continuity, Ben has made peace with this, but What If stories often exploit fractures. The prompt reveals Ben is "still feeling bitter at Reed\'s lie" — this is KEY emotional vulnerability. The symbiote doesn\'t just offer power; it offers VENGEANCE against Reed, VALIDATION of Ben\'s resentment, a chance to make Reed feel what Ben feels. For the symbiote, Ben is an IDEAL host: physically powerful (already super-strong), emotionally compromised (angry, isolated), and morally conflicted. The symbiote previously failed with Spider-Man (rejected) and will later bond with Eddie Brock, but Ben represents something unique — the unbreakable Thing made MORE unbreakable, the ever-lovin\' hero turned ever-LIVING weapon. The emotional core is betrayal — Reed created Ben\'s condition, and now Ben\'s choice to embrace the symbiote is the ultimate betrayal of their brotherhood. The FF aren\'t just teammates; they\'re FAMILY. Venom-Thing attacking them carries enormous emotional weight. The story likely builds to Ben confronting Reed, perhaps even hurting or killing him — the ultimate expression of "Dark."', 'step_number': 2, 'total_steps': 4, 'branch': 'character motivation', 'is_final': False}, name='sequential_thinking', type='tool_use')

content.content: {"status": "thought_recorded", "step_recorded": 2, "steps_remaining": 2, "total_steps_so_far": 2, "suggested_next_aspect": "emotional core and central themes", "instruction": "Step 2 recorded. Continue to step 3 \u2014 suggested focus: 'emotional core and central themes'. 2 step(s) remaining before is_final=true."}

content.data: ToolUseBlock(id='call_df7ffd20f5f34fa6a99d3744', caller=None, input={'thought': 'EMOTIONAL CORE & THEMES:\nThe central theme is "What makes a monster?" Ben Grimm is already visibly a monster — the Thing — but his heart has always been human, noble, the "ever-lovin\'" heart of the FF. The Venom symbiote doesn\'t change his outside; it corrupts his INSIDE. The irony is rich: Ben feared becoming a true monster, and by embracing the symbiote to feel powerful/accepted/avenged, he BECOMES what he always feared. Another theme: "The road to hell is paved with good intentions" — Ben may initially bond thinking he can control it, use it for good, or that it deserves a chance (like he does). But symbiotes amplify darkness. There\'s also the theme of ISOLATION — Ben has always felt alone as the only non-human FF member, the one who can\'t pass for normal, can\'t have Alicia Masters romantically (traditionally). The symbiote offers companionship: "We" instead of "I." This false intimacy is seductive. The emotional stakes are highest with Reed — their brotherhood, the core of the FF. Venom-Thing attacking Reed isn\'t just superhero vs supervillain violence; it\'s Cain and Abel, brother killing brother. The prompt\'s detail about Lizard biting off Reed\'s arm then head (while Venom-Thing watches "too late") is horrifying — Ben hesitates, perhaps his humanity surfaces, but it\'s TOO LATE. That moment encapsulates the tragedy: Ben fights the symbiote\'s influence but can\'t fully overcome it in time to save Reed. His partial resistance makes it MORE tragic, not less. If Ben were fully evil, it\'s simple villainy. If Ben TRIES to be good but fails because the symbiote is too powerful? That\'s horror. That\'s a "Dark" What If.', 'step_number': 3, 'total_steps': 4, 'branch': 'emotional core', 'is_final': False}, name='sequential_thinking', type='tool_use')

content.content: {"status": "thought_recorded", "step_recorded": 3, "steps_remaining": 1, "total_steps_so_far": 3, "suggested_next_aspect": "visual storytelling and iconic moments", "instruction": "Step 3 recorded. Continue to step 4 \u2014 suggested focus: 'visual storytelling and iconic moments'. 1 step(s) remaining before is_final=true."}

content.data: ToolUseBlock(id='call_fdc9305ab3c94446b9ffd0d3', caller=None, input={'thought': 'VISUAL STORYTELLING & ICONIC MOMENTS:\nVisually, Venom-Thing is extraordinary. The Thing\'s rocky, orange-crusted texture COMBINED with Venom\'s obsidian symbiote tendrils, white spider-symbol, and elongated jagged teeth/muscular tongue. Jethro Morales\'s art likely emphasizes CONTRAST: the symbiote\'s sleek liquid darkness wrapping around Ben\'s craggy solidity. Iconic imagery to capture: (1) The TRANSFORMATION moment — symbiote ooze spreading across Thing\'s rocky surface, tendrils probing his crevices, the merging of two distinct visual languages. (2) Venom-Thing\'s silhouette: massive, hulking, with symbiote tendrils forming extra "limbs," maybe the white spider-symbol distorted across rocky chest. (3) The EYES — both Ben\'s expressive eyes (visible in Thing form) and Venom\'s large white eyes — how do they merge? Perhaps Ben\'s human eyes visible THROUGH symbiote\'s white patches, showing internal conflict. (4) Action shots: Venom-Thing\'s strength ENHANCED — smashing through FF headquarters, lifting impossible weights, fighting multiple heroes at once. The symbiote might extend tendrils to attack while Ben\'s fists pummel. (5) The horror image: Reed\'s death — Lizard biting Reed\'s arm, then head, as Venom-Thing arrives. This needs to be handled carefully for video — focus on Ben\'s horrified reaction, the TOO LATE moment, rather than graphic gore. (6) Final image: Either Venom-Thing triumphant but ALONE, or perhaps Ben dying/rejecting the symbiote too late. The ending determines the visual beat — if Ben regains control moments before death, it\'s pathos; if he\'s lost forever, it\'s tragedy. Pacing should build: slow setup (Ben\'s return, emotional vulnerability), rising tension (symbiote whispers, Ben considers), explosive climax (bonding, fight, Reed\'s death), haunting resolution. The narrator\'s tone should match: grim, weighty, emphasizing the tragedy of a good man making one wrong choice with catastrophic consequences.', 'step_number': 4, 'total_steps': 4, 'branch': 'visual storytelling', 'is_final': True}, name='sequential_thinking', type='tool_use')

      "letterer": "Joe Sabino",
      "brief": "After returning from space post-Secret Wars, a bitter Ben Grimm discovers the Venom symbiote trapped in Reed Richards' lab. Still resentful over Reed's deception about curing his condition, Ben becomes vulnerable to the symbiote's influence and bonds with it. The result is catastrophic — Ben loses control, fights the Fantastic Four, and in a horrific climax, arrives too late to prevent the Lizard from brutally killing Reed Richards, biting off his arm and then his head. A tragic exploration of what happens when Marvel's strongest physical hero embraces its darkest amplification."
    }
  ],

    ],

      "Isolation and the seduction of false companionship ('We' vs 'I')",
      "What makes a monster? — Ben's physical form vs moral corruption",
      "The road to hell paved with good intentions",
      "Too little, too late — partial resistance leading to tragedy"
    ],

      "Thing's rocky orange texture merged with Venom's black symbiote tendrils",

      "Ben's expressive eyes visible through symbiote's white eye patches",

    "batcave_url": "https://batcave.biz/6587-what-if-dark-venom-2023.html"
  }

content: Great, I think you have enough information now. Please present the PHASE 2 CONFIRMATION outline with the scene breakdown so I can review it before you write the full script.

The outline is confirmed. Please generate the PHASE 3 SCRIPT with full narration text, image search queries, visual descriptions, moods, and effects for every scene. IMPORTANT:
1. For each scene, you MUST include 'source_issue' (e.g. '#121') and 'source_page' (integer or array of integers for the exact page number(s) where this moment occurs in that issue).
2. In comic_source, you MUST include 'batcave_url' — the full URL to the series page on batcave.biz (e.g. 'https://batcave.biz/6587-what-if-dark-venom-2023.html'). If you found it during web search, use that. Otherwise set it to empty string.
Use web_search if needed to find precise page numbers. Return ONLY the JSON.

{

Consumed by bitterness and the symbiote's seductive whispers, Ben bonds with the alien entity. The result is catastrophic: Venom-Thing unleashes devastation on the Fantastic Four, and in a horrific climax, Ben arrives too late to save Reed from a brutal death at the hands of the Lizard. Some betrayals can never be undone.",

    {
      "scene_id": 1,

    },
    {

      "source_issue": "#1",
      "source_page": [3, 4],
      "image_search_queries": [
        "What If Dark Venom #1 symbiote containment chamber Reed Richards lab comic panel",

        "What If...? Dark: Venom #1 symbiote trapped Fantastic Four laboratory"
      ],

      "effect": "slow_zoom_in"
    },
    {
      "scene_id": 3,
      "narration": "Ben discovers the truth. Reed's promise of a cure... was a lie. His oldest friend deceived him. The resentment begins to fester.",
      "source_issue": "#1",
      "source_page": [5, 6],
      "image_search_queries": [
        "What If Dark Venom #1 Ben confronts Reed about cure lie comic panel",
        "Thing Reed Richards argument confrontation comic panel Jethro Morales",
        "What If...? Dark: Venom #1 Ben angry at Reed betrayal scene"
      ],
      "visual_description": "Ben confronts Reed in the lab. Reed looks guilty, deflecting. Ben's rocky face shows dawning realization and rising anger. The symbiote's container visible nearby, perhaps pulsing.",

      "effect": "static"
    },
    {

      "mood": "seductive",
      "effect": "slow_zoom_in"
    },
    {

      "narration": "Ben gives in. The containment shatters. Darkness meets stone. The Ever-Lovin' Thing... becomes Venom.",
